title: Simulation/VR-Based Visualization and Problem-Solving Strategy Development for University Mathematics Instructional Design

context.prior_knowledge: Understanding of basic mathematical concepts (functions, calculus, probability, statistics) and experience with educational tools (GeoGebra, LMS), along with fundamental graph interpretation skills
context.additional_context: Instructional Design Strategy Curriculum for Developing University Mathematics Instructional Design Tools. Focuses on integrating VR simulations and formative assessment tools for conceptual understanding in core subjects such as Calculus and Linear Algebra, with particular emphasis on enhancing graph-based problem-solving and statistical analysis competencies.

learning_goals: Applying mathematical instructional design frameworks (ADDIE, Dick & Carey, Kemp) in simulation/VR environments, learners will implement and design provable logical structures for at least three visualization strategies of equations, functions, and geometry concepts.

Using learning design tools (GeoGebra, Desmos), learners will develop at least two formative assessment-focused instructional materials for graph interpretation (function graphs, statistical distributions) and probability distribution analysis.

Enhancing competency in visualizing mathematical concepts (function graphs, 3D shapes, probability distributions) via digital devices (20% improvement in pre-post assessments) and analyzing computational efficiency.

Learners will design at least three flexible teaching strategies (collaborative learning: group equation solving, flipped learning: pre-recorded lectures, personalized assignments: adjusting difficulty levels) for a medium-sized group (15â€“20 learners). They will achieve an 80%+ suitability score in peer and expert reviews and write a statistical analysis report for measuring learning outcomes.
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
